thread.title: How drunk? Estimates questioned in drunken-driving cases
thread.title_full: How drunk? Estimates questioned in drunken-driving cases

title: How drunk? Estimates questioned in drunken-driving cases
text: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y. -- Legal experts across the country are debating the effectiveness of something called "retrograde extrapolation." It's used mostly in drunken-driving cases to estimate the level of a person's intoxication, usually when they are arrested hours after a car crash. A Long Island prosecutor is using it to prosecute a man accused in a fiery crash that killed a father and his two young children. Although the driver had a blood-alcohol reading below the legal limit when he was arrested, authorities claim he was well over the limit when the crash occurred. The driver's attorney and drunken-driving experts around the country contend the extrapolation is an unreliable measure of a person's intoxication. Some states require prosecutors to merely use the blood-alcohol readings taken at the time of a person's arrest. Share this page
